captions.text:
The remains of World War One soldiers killed
almost a hundred years ago have finally been
discovered due to the work of a group of archaeologists.

In the region of Champagne-Ardenne, in north
east France on Friday afternoon, local volunteers

unearthed a network of trenches and tunnels
filled in by farmers after the war.

This is the complete skeleton of an unidentified
German soldier, which is housed in the region's

The soldier was aged between 20 and 25-years-old
when he was killed, and the uniform and equipment

found buried in his grave meant it was possible
to identify him as German.

The former natural fortress saw vast activity
on Champagne's far-right front line in the

Its pivotal position between the Champagne
and Argonne fronts made it an important strategic

point for both sides - with both German and
French forces taking control over the complex
puzzle of trenches during the war.

Over 16 million people lost their lives during
World War One, and at the time it was described
as the war to end all wars.

title: Skeletons of WW1 soldiers discovered in excavated former trenches

comments.text:
And at the Battle of the Somme they were told (by Haig) to go at walking 
pace across no-mans land (much easier target for the German machine 
guns!)   Haig and the other officers in charge (sitting safely somewhere no 
doubt drinking cups of tea) did not expect that our soldiers would be met 
with resistance (after bombing them for 5 or so days).  So when the Germans 
came up from their 30-40 foot trenches virtually unharmed and returned to 
their machine guns, our men were flattened.  But the murderous (no doubt 
ignorant, pompous) imbeciles in charge (i.e. Haig) didn't have the nouse to 
change plans and went on to order 3 waves of men over the top to their 
death.   And those that wouldn't go, as we know, got shot.  It's the 
officers who should have been shot.  You are right, horrendous war crimes.

comments.author: Land hoe

comments.text:
+Land hoe
 mine is not ideology, and just to clarify this I have no problem to say 
that I'm happy that Germany was defeated in WWII, as I think a germany-led 
world would have been a much worse world that the one we have today, 
despite all its problems and limits.
But it's a matter of fact that the US Army (and the British, and the 
Canadian, with troops from other commonwealth countries and dominions ) in 
France had to fight against a smaller part of the Wermacht, as the biggest 
part was still fighting the Russians in the eastern front. At the end of 
June 44 there were already more than 2 million allied soldiers in Normandy 
(most of them were Americans), facing more or less half million of German 
troops, so the ratio was 4:1 in favour of the allied. Furthermore, the 
allied had total air supremacy and more than 10000 tanks, while germans 
only 2000. So their supremacy was overwhelming, but it took them almost 
three months for taking Paris, and almost nine for crossing the German 
border. Certainly not what one would expect given the superiority.
